shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: shelljs 0.3.0 from grunt-if 0.2.0 (BDSA-2022-0115)

fullDescription.text:
ShellJS is vulnerable to information disclosure due to the unsafe handling of the `stdout` and `stderr` streams of the `shell.exec()` function. A local attacker could potentially obtain sensitive data that has been produced by processes by examining the `stdout` file that is produced by ShellJS. This vulnerability can also be leveraged to crash privileged ShellJS processes.

It should be noted that only the synchronous version of `shell.exec()` function is affected by this issue.

help.markdown:

| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| shelljs 0.3.0  | 0.8.5  | 0.8.5 |

## Description
ShellJS is vulnerable to information disclosure due to the unsafe handling of the `stdout` and `stderr` streams of the `shell.exec()` function. A local attacker could potentially obtain sensitive data that has been produced by processes by examining the `stdout` file that is produced by ShellJS. This vulnerability can also be leveraged to crash privileged ShellJS processes.

It should be noted that only the synchronous version of `shell.exec()` function is affected by this issue.

Fixed in version [**0.8.5**](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/releases/tag/v0.8.5) by [this](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/commit/d919d22dd6de385edaa9d90313075a77f74b338c) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/releases).

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: shelljs 0.3.0 from grunt-if 0.2.0 (CVE-2022-0144 BDSA-2022-0052)

fullDescription.text:
ShellJS is vulnerable to privilege escalation and denial-of-service (DoS) issues due to how file permissions used by the internal implementation of `shell.exec()` are mishandled.

If ShellJS scripts running locally are using the ShellJS `exec()` function, an attacker with low-level privileges on the system could abuse the flaw in order to leak sensitive information, such as passwords, in order to perform local privilege escalation or shutdown privileged ShellJS processes.

A vendor comment [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/issues/1058#issuecomment-1008657537) indicates that this issue only impacts the `synchronous` version of `shell.exec()`. All other ShellJS methods (including the `async` usage of `shell.exec()`) should not be impacted.

If ShellJS scripts running locally are using the ShellJS `exec()` function, an attacker with low-level privileges on the system could abuse the flaw in order to leak sensitive information, such as passwords, in order to perform local privilege escalation or shutdown privileged ShellJS processes.

A vendor comment [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/issues/1058#issuecomment-1008657537) indicates that this issue only impacts the `synchronous` version of `shell.exec()`. All other ShellJS methods (including the `async` usage of `shell.exec()`) should not be impacted.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 1.2.0 from grunt-jsbeautifier 0.2.13 (CVE-2021-44906 BDSA-2022-0771)

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 4.17.11 from grunt-if 0.2.0 (BDSA-2019-3842)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.

This is better known as a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).

## Description
Mixin-deep is vulnerable to prototype pollution attack. This could allow an attacker to manipulate a function to add or modify properties of `Object.prototype` via a constructor payload. Successfully exploiting results in a denial-of-service (DoS) and code execution may be possible.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2019-2162](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2019-2162)([CVE-2019-10746](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-10746)) - Mixin-deep Vulnerable to Denial-of-Service (DoS) Due to Prototype Pollution Attack via 'Object.prototype'


## Solution
Fixed in:

* **[1.3.2](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/releases/tag/1.3.2)** by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/commit/90ee1fab375fccfd9b926df718243339b4976d50) commit.
* **[2.0.1](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/releases/tag/2.0.1)** by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/commit/8f464c8ce9761a8c9c2b3457eaeee9d404fa7af9) commit.

## Workaround
1. Freeze the prototype— use Object.freeze (Object.prototype).
2. Require schema validation of JSON input.
3. Avoid using unsafe recursive merge functions.
4. Consider using objects without prototypes (for example, Object.create(null)), breaking the prototype chain and preventing pollution.
5. As a best practice use Map instead of Object.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: set-value 2.0.0 from nodemon 1.19.1 (CVE-2019-10747 BDSA-2019-4362)

fullDescription.text:
set-value is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient input validation.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to modify the Object prototype properties which causes additional properties or changes to the objects which could result in denial-of-service (DoS) or alter the integrity of the application. If the application uses polluted objects in conjunction with code execution primitives (such as eval), it may be possible for an attacker to execute malicious code.

It was later determined that this issue could be bypassed via a type confusion vulnerability as noted in **CVE-2021-23440** (**BDSA-2021-2911**).

An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to modify the Object prototype properties which causes additional properties or changes to the objects which could result in denial-of-service (DoS) or alter the integrity of the application. If the application uses polluted objects in conjunction with code execution primitives (such as eval), it may be possible for an attacker to execute malicious code.

It was later determined that this issue could be bypassed via a type confusion vulnerability as noted in **CVE-2021-23440** (**BDSA-2021-2911**).

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: uglify-js 2.4.24 from swig 1.4.2 (CVE-2015-8858 BDSA-2015-0031)

fullDescription.text:
The uglify-js package is vulnerable to a denial-of-service condition due to CPU consumption when parsing a certain types of input. This can cause an application running the uglify-js package to hang by blocking the event loop. 

An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying crafted input to the `parse()` function call.

## Description
The uglify-js package is vulnerable to a denial-of-service condition due to CPU consumption when parsing a certain types of input. This can cause an application running the uglify-js package to hang by blocking the event loop. 

An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying crafted input to the `parse()` function call.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2015-0031](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2015-0031)([CVE-2015-8858](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2015-8858)) - Node.js uglify-js package is Vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) via Crafted Input to 'parse'


## Solution
Fixed in version [**2.6.0**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/uglify-js).

Fixed under Debian package via experimental repository in version [**3.3.10-1**](https://wiki.debian.org/DebianExperimental).

Note: Experimental is a staging/collaboration/experimental area for development and is not fit for production.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 2.4.2 from zaproxy 0.2.0 (BDSA-2019-3842)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 2.4.2 from zaproxy 0.2.0 (CVE-2018-16487 BDSA-2018-3818)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.

## Description
Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.

## Solution
Fixed in version [**4.17.11**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.11) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/90e6199a161b6445b01454517b40ef65ebecd2ad) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tags).

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 2.4.2 from zaproxy 0.2.0 (CVE-2020-8203 BDSA-2020-1674)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 4.17.11 from async 2.6.1 (BDSA-2019-3842)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

## Description
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-2632](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-2632)([CVE-2021-37712](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-37712)) - tar Vulnerable to Arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite/Code Execution via Directory Cache Poisoning


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**4.4.18**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.18) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/3f2e2da3866c4e5f26ca0c0d6721cb371c5a3933) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/bb93ba243746f705092905da1955ac3b0509ba1e). 
* [**5.0.10**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.10) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/ab3e9036dc4504413fb6f154ea6943af5c187e26) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/1739408d3122af897caefd09662bce2ea477533b) commit. 
* [**6.1.9**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.9) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/b6162c7fafe797f856564ef37f4b82747f051455) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/53602669f58ddbeb3294d7196b3320aaaed22728) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).

## Workaround
Users can workaround this vulnerability by creating a custom filter method (`x` in this example) which prevents all symbolic links from being extracted:

```
const tar = require('tar')

tar.x({
  file: 'archive.tgz',
  filter: (file, entry) => {
    if (entry.type === 'SymbolicLink') {
      return false
    } else {
      return true
    }
  }
})
```

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: tar 4.4.8 from nodemon 1.19.1 (CVE-2021-32803 BDSA-2021-2334)

fullDescription.text:
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Description
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-2334](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-2334)([CVE-2021-32803](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-32803)) - node-tar Vulnerable to Arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite via Insufficient Symlink Protection due to Directory Cache Poisoning


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**3.2.3**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v3.2.3) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/85d3a942b4064e4ff171f91696fced7975167349) commit,
* [**4.4.15**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.15) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/46fe35083e2676e31c4e0a81639dce6da7aaa356) commit, 
* [**5.0.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/5987d9a41f6bfbf1ddab1098e1fdcf1a5618f571) commit, 
* [**6.1.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/9dbdeb6df8e9dbd96fa9e84341b9d74734be6c20) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases).

## Workaround
It is suggested on [npmjs.com](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1771#workarounds) that it is possible to mitigate the vulnerability by creating a custom `onentry` method which sanitizes the `entry.path` or a `filter` method which removes entries with absolute paths.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: shelljs 0.3.0 from jshint 2.12.0 (BDSA-2022-0115)

fullDescription.text:
ShellJS is vulnerable to information disclosure due to the unsafe handling of the `stdout` and `stderr` streams of the `shell.exec()` function. A local attacker could potentially obtain sensitive data that has been produced by processes by examining the `stdout` file that is produced by ShellJS. This vulnerability can also be leveraged to crash privileged ShellJS processes.

It should be noted that only the synchronous version of `shell.exec()` function is affected by this issue.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: shelljs 0.3.0 from jshint 2.12.0 (CVE-2022-0144 BDSA-2022-0052)

fullDescription.text:
ShellJS is vulnerable to privilege escalation and denial-of-service (DoS) issues due to how file permissions used by the internal implementation of `shell.exec()` are mishandled.

If ShellJS scripts running locally are using the ShellJS `exec()` function, an attacker with low-level privileges on the system could abuse the flaw in order to leak sensitive information, such as passwords, in order to perform local privilege escalation or shutdown privileged ShellJS processes.

A vendor comment [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/issues/1058#issuecomment-1008657537) indicates that this issue only impacts the `synchronous` version of `shell.exec()`. All other ShellJS methods (including the `async` usage of `shell.exec()`) should not be impacted.

* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-269](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/269.html)
help.text:
ShellJS is vulnerable to privilege escalation and denial-of-service (DoS) issues due to how file permissions used by the internal implementation of `shell.exec()` are mishandled.

If ShellJS scripts running locally are using the ShellJS `exec()` function, an attacker with low-level privileges on the system could abuse the flaw in order to leak sensitive information, such as passwords, in order to perform local privilege escalation or shutdown privileged ShellJS processes.

A vendor comment [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/issues/1058#issuecomment-1008657537) indicates that this issue only impacts the `synchronous` version of `shell.exec()`. All other ShellJS methods (including the `async` usage of `shell.exec()`) should not be impacted.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: babel-traverse 6.11.4 from grunt-if 0.2.0 (BDSA-2023-2769)

fullDescription.text:
Babel Travserse is vulnerable to an arbitrary code execution issue due to how the `_evaluate()` function allows for the evaluation of inherited methods. This affects plugins that rely on the `path.evaluate()` or `path.evaluateTruthy()` internal Babel methods.

In cases where Babel is used to compile untrusted code, an attacker could potentially submit specially crafted code that, during compilation, could be evaluated and executed during the compilation process.

## Description
Babel Travserse is vulnerable to an arbitrary code execution issue due to how the `_evaluate()` function allows for the evaluation of inherited methods. This affects plugins that rely on the `path.evaluate()` or `path.evaluateTruthy()` internal Babel methods.

In cases where Babel is used to compile untrusted code, an attacker could potentially submit specially crafted code that, during compilation, could be evaluated and executed during the compilation process.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2023-2769](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2023-2769) - Babel Traverse Vulnerable to Arbitrary Code Execution via Evaluation of Inherited Methods



## Solution
Fixed in [**8.0.0-alpha4**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse/v/8.0.0-alpha.4) and [**7.23.2**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse/v/7.23.2) by [this](https://github.com/babel/babel/commit/b13376b346946e3f62fc0848c1d2a23223314c82) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse).

## Workaround
The vendor has provided the following workaround suggestion in their [advisory](https://github.com/babel/babel/security/advisories/GHSA-67hx-6x53-jw92):
> If you cannot upgrade `@babel/traverse` and are using one of the affected packages, upgrade them to their latest version to avoid triggering the vulnerable code path in affected `@babel/traverse` versions:
> 
>     @babel/plugin-transform-runtime v7.23.2
>     @babel/preset-env v7.23.2
>     @babel/helper-define-polyfill-provider v0.4.3
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-corejs2 v0.4.6
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-corejs3 v0.8.5
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-es-shims v0.10.0
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-regenerator v0.5.3

## Description
glob-parent contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2021-1936](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-1936)([CVE-2020-28469](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-28469)) - glob-parent Vulnerable to Denial-of-Service (DoS) via Regular Expressions in 'enclosure' Variable


## Solution
Fixed in [**5.1.2**](https://github.com/gulpjs/glob-parent/releases/tag/v5.1.2) by [this](https://github.com/gulpjs/glob-parent/commit/f9231168b0041fea3f8f954b3cceb56269fc6366) commit. 

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/glob-parent).

- owasp-nodejs-goat/1.3.0/-npm

        - grunt-contrib-nodeunit/1.0.0
            - nodeunit/0.9.5
                - tap/7.1.2
                    - nyc/7.1.0
                        - micromatch/2.3.11
                            - parse-glob/3.0.4
                                - glob-base/0.3.0
                                    - glob-parent/2.0.0

## Description
npm-user-validate is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to the way it handles some long input strings. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to push the program into an extreme state, eventually bringing it to a halt, denial-of-service (DoS) condition.

## Solution

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/npm-user-validate/tags)

## Description
Node Semver is vulnerable due to improper handling of whitespaces. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by providing a crafted input in order to cause a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2023-2207](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2023-2207)([CVE-2022-25883](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-25883)) - Node Semver Vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) via Improper Handling of Whitespace in 'range.js' File


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**7.5.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/releases/tag/v7.5.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/commit/717534ee353682f3bcf33e60a8af4292626d4441) commit 
* [**6.3.1**](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/releases/tag/v6.3.1) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/commit/928e56d21150da0413a3333a3148b20e741a920c) commit
* [**5.7.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/releases/tag/v5.7.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/commit/2f8fd41487acf380194579ecb6f8b1bbfe116be0) commit

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/releases).

## Description
qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.

## Solution
Fixed in [**6.10.3**](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.10.3) by [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/8b4cc14cda94a5c89341b77e5fe435ec6c41be2d) commit.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 0.0.10 from forever 2.0.0 (CVE-2020-7598 BDSA-2020-4373)

fullDescription.text:
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

## Description
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

:orange_circle: [BDSA-2020-4373](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2020-4373)([CVE-2020-7598](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-7598)) - minimist Vulnerable to Remote Code Execution (RCE) via Prototype Pollution


## Solution
Fixed in version [**1.2.6**](https://github.com/substack/minimist/releases/tag/1.2.6) by [this](https://github.com/substack/minimist/commit/c2b981977fa834b223b408cfb860f933c9811e4d) commit. 

The latest releases can be found [here](https://github.com/substack/minimist/tags)

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 0.0.10 from forever 2.0.0 (CVE-2021-44906 BDSA-2022-0771)

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

## Description
Marked is vulnerable to regular expression denial of service (ReDoS) due to a flaw present within a regular expression in the `src/rules.js` file. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted input in order to consume resources, thus resulting in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition occurring.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2022-0106](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2022-0106)([CVE-2022-21680](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-21680)) - Marked Vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via 'block.def'


## Solution
Fixed in version [**4.0.10**](https://github.com/markedjs/marked/releases/tag/v4.0.10) by [this](https://github.com/markedjs/marked/commit/c4a3ccd344b6929afa8a1d50ac54a721e57012c0) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/markedjs/marked/tags).

## Workaround
The vendor has proposed the following workaround:

> Do not run untrusted markdown through Marked or run Marked on a worker thread and set a reasonable time limit to prevent draining resources.

An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted input in order to consume resources, thus resulting in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition occurring.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 0.0.8 from grunt-mocha-test 0.12.7 (CVE-2021-44906 BDSA-2022-0771)

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

## Description
JSON Pointer is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack due to a type confusion error. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-3432](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-3432)([CVE-2021-23807](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-23807)) - JSON Pointer Vulnerable to Prototype Pollution via Type Confusion


## Solution
Fixed in [**5.0.0**](https://github.com/janl/node-jsonpointer/releases/tag/v5.0.0) by [this](https://github.com/janl/node-jsonpointer/commit/a0345f3550cd9c4d89f33b126390202b89510ad4) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/janl/node-jsonpointer/releases).

handlebars.js, an extension to Mustache, contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. An attacker could exploit this issue by accessing prototype properties and methods, which may result in the attacker being able to force an application crash or gain the ability to execute arbitrary code.

:orange_circle: [BDSA-2020-4765](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2020-4765) - handlebars.js Vulnerable to Prototype Pollution via Missing Access Restrictions



## Solution
Fixed in version [**4.6.0**](https://github.com/handlebars-lang/handlebars.js/releases/tag/v4.6.0) by [this](https://github.com/handlebars-lang/handlebars.js/commit/d03b6ecfc44e350fd08df752a9551d824287d7f5) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/handlebars-lang/handlebars.js/tags).

## Description
The handlebars package is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) and remote code execution (RCE) attacks due to improper validation of user-supplied input. In a cross-site scripting scenario, an attacker could exploit this to pass malicious arbitrary JavaScript into template, which will execute when a victim visits the crafted page. If handlebars is used to run on the server side, remote code execution is possible.

## Description
Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

## Solution
Fixed in **[4.17.20](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.20)**.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 4.17.11 from grunt-contrib-watch 1.1.0 (BDSA-2019-3842)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

## Description
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

The NPM CLI is vulnerable to arbitrary file write via a symlink. An attacker must trick their target into installing a package with a crafted `bin` entry.

Fixed in [**6.13.3**](https://github.com/npm/cli/releases/tag/v6.13.3) by [this](https://github.com/npm/cli/commit/19ce061a2ee165d8de862c8f0f733c222846b9e1) commit.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 4.17.11 from cypress 3.3.1 (BDSA-2019-3842)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Workaround
A patch has been proposed [here](https://github.com/request/request/pull/3444/commits/d42332182512e56ba68446f49c3e3711e04301a2) that has not been merged with the upstream repository yet.

## Description
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-2631](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-2631)([CVE-2021-37701](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-37701)) - tar Vulnerable to Arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite/Code Execution via Directory Cache Poisoning


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**4.4.16**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.16) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/3f2e2da3866c4e5f26ca0c0d6721cb371c5a3933) commit. 
* [**5.0.8**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.8) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/ab3e9036dc4504413fb6f154ea6943af5c187e26)commit. 
* [**6.1.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/53602669f58ddbeb3294d7196b3320aaaed22728) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).

## Workaround
Users can workaround this vulnerability by creating a custom filter method (`x` in this example) which prevents all symbolic links from being extracted:

```
const tar = require('tar')

tar.x({
  file: 'archive.tgz',
  filter: (file, entry) => {
    if (entry.type === 'SymbolicLink') {
      return false
    } else {
      return true
    }
  }
})
```

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: tar 2.2.1 from grunt-npm-install 0.3.1 (CVE-2021-32803 BDSA-2021-2334)

fullDescription.text:
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Description
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-2334](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-2334)([CVE-2021-32803](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-32803)) - node-tar Vulnerable to Arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite via Insufficient Symlink Protection due to Directory Cache Poisoning


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**3.2.3**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v3.2.3) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/85d3a942b4064e4ff171f91696fced7975167349) commit,
* [**4.4.15**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.15) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/46fe35083e2676e31c4e0a81639dce6da7aaa356) commit, 
* [**5.0.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/5987d9a41f6bfbf1ddab1098e1fdcf1a5618f571) commit, 
* [**6.1.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/9dbdeb6df8e9dbd96fa9e84341b9d74734be6c20) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases).

## Workaround
It is suggested on [npmjs.com](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1771#workarounds) that it is possible to mitigate the vulnerability by creating a custom `onentry` method which sanitizes the `entry.path` or a `filter` method which removes entries with absolute paths.

## Description
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-2632](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-2632)([CVE-2021-37712](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-37712)) - tar Vulnerable to Arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite/Code Execution via Directory Cache Poisoning


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**4.4.18**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.18) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/3f2e2da3866c4e5f26ca0c0d6721cb371c5a3933) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/bb93ba243746f705092905da1955ac3b0509ba1e). 
* [**5.0.10**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.10) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/ab3e9036dc4504413fb6f154ea6943af5c187e26) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/1739408d3122af897caefd09662bce2ea477533b) commit. 
* [**6.1.9**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.9) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/b6162c7fafe797f856564ef37f4b82747f051455) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/53602669f58ddbeb3294d7196b3320aaaed22728) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).

## Workaround
Users can workaround this vulnerability by creating a custom filter method (`x` in this example) which prevents all symbolic links from being extracted:

```
const tar = require('tar')

tar.x({
  file: 'archive.tgz',
  filter: (file, entry) => {
    if (entry.type === 'SymbolicLink') {
      return false
    } else {
      return true
    }
  }
})
```

## Description

:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2017-3089](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2017-3089)([CVE-2017-1000048](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-1000048)) - qs Vulnerable to Denial-of-Service (DoS) via Prototype Override Protection Bypass


## Solution
Fixed by [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/760d0a13912f788893b55d8f295dd47520b9d397) commit and [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/1c045cac47718c1c18c08df770ca0451e66e4e62) commit in:
* **[6.4.0](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.4.0)**
* **[6.3.2](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.3.2)**
* **[6.2.3](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.2.3)**
* **[6.1.2](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.1.2)**
* **[6.0.4](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.0.4)**

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases).

Note: initially the vendor partially fixed this issue with [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/beade029171b8cef9cee0d03ebe577e2dd84976d) commit, before it was discovered that this still allowed an attacker to exploit the issue using a prefixed `[` character, thus the above further commits were required.



## Dependency tree

    - grunt-retire/0.3.12
        - request/2.67.0
            - qs/5.2.1

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 0.0.8 from forever 2.0.0 (CVE-2020-7598 BDSA-2020-4373)

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

## Description
qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.

## Description
Node.js Hawk contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a crash.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2022-1262](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2022-1262)([CVE-2022-29167](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-29167)) - Node.js Hawk Vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial-of-Service via 'parseHost' Function


## Solution
Fixed in [**9.0.1**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk/v/9.0.1) by [this](https://github.com/mozilla/hawk/commit/d10d72ca82db967f6c5fcf866ff78e3ca25ce1ab) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk).

## Workaround
The vendor has issued the following workaround:

"`Hawk.authenticate()` accepts the options argument. If that contains host and port, those would be used instead of a call to `utils.parseHost()`".

## Description
Node.js Hawk contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a crash.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2022-1262](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2022-1262)([CVE-2022-29167](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-29167)) - Node.js Hawk Vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial-of-Service via 'parseHost' Function


## Solution
Fixed in [**9.0.1**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk/v/9.0.1) by [this](https://github.com/mozilla/hawk/commit/d10d72ca82db967f6c5fcf866ff78e3ca25ce1ab) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk).

## Workaround
The vendor has issued the following workaround:

"`Hawk.authenticate()` accepts the options argument. If that contains host and port, those would be used instead of a call to `utils.parseHost()`".

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: fsevents 1.2.9 from forever 2.0.0 (CVE-2023-45311 BDSA-2023-1218)

fullDescription.text:
fsevents npm package is vulnerable to hijacking due to malicious code run during installation via a hijacked URL in the install configuration. This would allow the current owner of the URL to run code of their choosing on each installation of the package.

**Note:** Originally, the credentials to the S3 bucket of the affected URL were [lost](https://github.com/fsevents/fsevents/releases/tag/v1.2.11). It was demonstrated by a security researcher that the bucket became available to register once again, and it was taken over by the researcher to demonstrate possible impact of this vulnerability. At this time, AWS has taken possession of the S3 bucket and currently blocks all access, neutralizing any threat. Should this bucket become available to use in the future, affected versions of fsevents will once again become vulnerable. This occurred in August 2023, when the bucket was briefly reinstated in error.

:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2017-3089](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2017-3089)([CVE-2017-1000048](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-1000048)) - qs Vulnerable to Denial-of-Service (DoS) via Prototype Override Protection Bypass


## Solution
Fixed by [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/760d0a13912f788893b55d8f295dd47520b9d397) commit and [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/1c045cac47718c1c18c08df770ca0451e66e4e62) commit in:

* **[6.0.4](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.0.4)**

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases).

Note: initially the vendor partially fixed this issue with [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/beade029171b8cef9cee0d03ebe577e2dd84976d) commit, before it was discovered that this still allowed an attacker to exploit the issue using a prefixed `[` character, thus the above further commits were required.

fullDescription.text: Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2023-0576](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2023-0576)([CVE-2023-28155](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-28155)) - Request Package Vulnerable to Server Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via Cross-Protocol Redirects using a Malicious Server




## Workaround
A patch has been proposed [here](https://github.com/request/request/pull/3444/commits/d42332182512e56ba68446f49c3e3711e04301a2) that has not been merged with the upstream repository yet.

## Dependency tree

            - request/2.79.0

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: fsevents 1.2.9 from nodemon 1.19.1 (CVE-2023-45311 BDSA-2023-1218)

fullDescription.text:
fsevents npm package is vulnerable to hijacking due to malicious code run during installation via a hijacked URL in the install configuration. This would allow the current owner of the URL to run code of their choosing on each installation of the package.

**Note:** Originally, the credentials to the S3 bucket of the affected URL were [lost](https://github.com/fsevents/fsevents/releases/tag/v1.2.11). It was demonstrated by a security researcher that the bucket became available to register once again, and it was taken over by the researcher to demonstrate possible impact of this vulnerability. At this time, AWS has taken possession of the S3 bucket and currently blocks all access, neutralizing any threat. Should this bucket become available to use in the future, affected versions of fsevents will once again become vulnerable. This occurred in August 2023, when the bucket was briefly reinstated in error.

help.markdown:

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 0.0.8 from swig 1.4.2 (CVE-2021-44906 BDSA-2022-0771)

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 4.13.1 from grunt-if 0.2.0 (BDSA-2019-3842)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: lodash 4.13.1 from grunt-if 0.2.0 (CVE-2018-16487 BDSA-2018-3818)

fullDescription.text:
Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.

## Description
Hawk, a HTTP authentication scheme, is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (*ReDoS*) due to its implementation of pattern matching.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2016-0224](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2016-0224)([CVE-2016-2515](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2016-2515)) - Node.js Hawk Vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial-of-Service via Crafted Headers or URIs


## Solution
Fixed in [**3.1.3**](https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/releases/tag/v3.1.3) by [this](https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/commit/ccebde4b24d06014ac573888a21813b29a4a16c7) commit.
Fixed in [**4.1.1**](https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/releases/tag/v4.1.1) by [this](https://github.com/hueniverse/hawk/commit/0833f99ba64558525995a7e21d4093da1f3e15fa) commit.

            - hawk/1.0.0

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 0.0.10 from swig 1.4.2 (CVE-2020-7598 BDSA-2020-4373)

fullDescription.text:
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

## Description
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 0.0.10 from swig 1.4.2 (CVE-2021-44906 BDSA-2022-0771)

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

## Description
js-yaml is vulnerable to code injection due to incorrect parsing of YAML documents. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted YAML file to a vulnerable application using js-yaml and the unsafe `load()` function to parse YAML data.

## Solution

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: moment 2.24.0 from cypress 3.3.1 (CVE-2022-31129 BDSA-2022-1914)

fullDescription.text:
Moment.js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to an inefficient regular expression in use within the `rfc2822` parsing code.

An attacker could submit a crafted input containing more that 10,000 characters in order to trigger an excessive consumption of resources that result in a slowdown of processing.

## Description
Moment.js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to an inefficient regular expression in use within the `rfc2822` parsing code.

An attacker could submit a crafted input containing more that 10,000 characters in order to trigger an excessive consumption of resources that result in a slowdown of processing.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2022-1914](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2022-1914)([CVE-2022-31129](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-31129)) - Node.js 'Moment.js' Package Vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) via Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity in 'rfc2822' Parsing Code


## Solution
Fixed in [**2.29.4**](https://github.com/moment/moment/releases/tag/2.29.4) by [this](https://github.com/moment/moment/commit/9a3b5894f3d5d602948ac8a02e4ee528a49ca3a3) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/moment).

**Note**: The vendor has stated in their [advisory](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-wc69-rhjr-hc9g) that the patch for **2.29.4** can be applied to all affected versions with minimal tweaking.

## Workaround
The vendor has suggested [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-wc69-rhjr-hc9g) that users of Moment.js who pass a user-supplied string to a constructor should apply input length filters to help with this issue, and other potential future regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issues.

        - moment/2.24.0

## Description
moment is vulnerable to path traversal which may lead to the modification of sensitive information within a file directory on the file system. An attacker can exploit this flaw by manipulating directory pathways using unwanted characters to access and modify a resource that is outside the intended directory.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [BDSA-2022-0897](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2022-0897)([CVE-2022-24785](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-24785)) - moment Vulnerable to Path Traversal via 'loadLocale()' Function


## Solution
Fixed in version [**2.29.2**](https://github.com/moment/moment/releases/tag/2.29.2) by [this](https://github.com/moment/moment/commit/4211bfc8f15746be4019bba557e29a7ba83d54c5) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/tags).

## Workaround
The vendor has stated [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-8hfj-j24r-96c4) the following workaround:

"Sanitize user-provided locale name before passing it to moment.js".

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Workaround
A patch has been proposed [here](https://github.com/request/request/pull/3444/commits/d42332182512e56ba68446f49c3e3711e04301a2) that has not been merged with the upstream repository yet.

message.text:
ShellJS is vulnerable to information disclosure due to the unsafe handling of the `stdout` and `stderr` streams of the `shell.exec()` function. A local attacker could potentially obtain sensitive data that has been produced by processes by examining the `stdout` file that is produced by ShellJS. This vulnerability can also be leveraged to crash privileged ShellJS processes.

It should be noted that only the synchronous version of `shell.exec()` function is affected by this issue.

ShellJS is vulnerable to privilege escalation and denial-of-service (DoS) issues due to how file permissions used by the internal implementation of `shell.exec()` are mishandled.

If ShellJS scripts running locally are using the ShellJS `exec()` function, an attacker with low-level privileges on the system could abuse the flaw in order to leak sensitive information, such as passwords, in order to perform local privilege escalation or shutdown privileged ShellJS processes.

A vendor comment [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/issues/1058#issuecomment-1008657537) indicates that this issue only impacts the `synchronous` version of `shell.exec()`. All other ShellJS methods (including the `async` usage of `shell.exec()`) should not be impacted.

Minimatch package contains a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) vulnerability because of improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this flaw by calling the `braceExpand()` function with specific arguments.

bl is vulnerable to information exposure and denial-of-service (DoS) due to the improper handling of buffer operations. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a system with maliciously crafted input.

inflect is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to improperly defined regular expressions for classifications and underscoring. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying an application with maliciously crafted input.
Growl is vulnerable to command injection as it does not sufficiently sanitize the user-supplied input before passing it to `exec`. This can lead to arbitrary code execution on the vulnerable system.

The ini package is vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks.  A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. The impact of this vulnerability is reliant on the ini package parsing a untrusted input.

qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.
Tunnel-Agent contains a memory exposure vulnerability due to improper input validation allowing a numeric value for `auth`.
Tunnel-Agent contains a memory exposure vulnerability due to improper input validation allowing a numeric value for `auth`.

Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).
Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).
Lodash is vulnerable to command injection via the `template` function. An attacker can take advantage of this vulnerability in order to run arbitrary commands.

Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

lodash is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to functionality that allows users to influence protoypes. An attacker could cause a vulnerable application to crash by providing malicious input that modifies JavaScript prototypes within the application. It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.

Async is vulnerable to a prototype pollution issue. A remote attacker may be able to abuse this issue in order to execute arbitrary code, obtain privileges, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it. Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

decode-uri-component contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. Successful exploitation of this issue enables an unauthenticated attacker to cause an application crash within the decoding process, by supplying a crafted input file.

bl is vulnerable to information exposure and denial-of-service (DoS) due to the improper handling of buffer operations. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a system with maliciously crafted input.

The websocket-extensions npm package is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper regular expression parsing with WebSocket handshakes. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a system with maliciously crafted requests.

The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

ShellJS is vulnerable to information disclosure due to the unsafe handling of the `stdout` and `stderr` streams of the `shell.exec()` function. A local attacker could potentially obtain sensitive data that has been produced by processes by examining the `stdout` file that is produced by ShellJS. This vulnerability can also be leveraged to crash privileged ShellJS processes.

It should be noted that only the synchronous version of `shell.exec()` function is affected by this issue.

ShellJS is vulnerable to privilege escalation and denial-of-service (DoS) issues due to how file permissions used by the internal implementation of `shell.exec()` are mishandled.

If ShellJS scripts running locally are using the ShellJS `exec()` function, an attacker with low-level privileges on the system could abuse the flaw in order to leak sensitive information, such as passwords, in order to perform local privilege escalation or shutdown privileged ShellJS processes.

A vendor comment [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/issues/1058#issuecomment-1008657537) indicates that this issue only impacts the `synchronous` version of `shell.exec()`. All other ShellJS methods (including the `async` usage of `shell.exec()`) should not be impacted.

Mime is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to a poorly implemented regular expression.  A remote attacker could impact the performance of a vulnerable application, or perhaps cause it to crash, by causing it to process a maliciously crafted path.

The ini package is vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks.  A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. The impact of this vulnerability is reliant on the ini package parsing a untrusted input.

qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.
Node.js module sshpk is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to a mistake in the implementation of regular expression matching.

Minimatch package contains a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) vulnerability because of improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this flaw by calling the `braceExpand()` function with specific arguments.

tough-cookie is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to improper handling of cookies when using `CookieJar` in `rejectPublicSuffixes=false` mode.  An attacker can use this vulnerability to override the global object prototype in order to cause unspecified impacts.
Directory traversal vulnerability in swig-templates thru 2.0.4 and swig thru 1.4.2, allows attackers to read arbitrary files via the include or extends tags.

Minimatch package contains a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) vulnerability because of improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this flaw by calling the `braceExpand()` function with specific arguments.

Minimatch package contains a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) vulnerability because of improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this flaw by calling the `braceExpand()` function with specific arguments.
Node.js Hawk contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a crash.

Vercel ms contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a system crash.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2015-8315**.

fsevents npm package is vulnerable to hijacking due to malicious code run during installation via a hijacked URL in the install configuration. This would allow the current owner of the URL to run code of their choosing on each installation of the package.

**Note:** Originally, the credentials to the S3 bucket of the affected URL were [lost](https://github.com/fsevents/fsevents/releases/tag/v1.2.11). It was demonstrated by a security researcher that the bucket became available to register once again, and it was taken over by the researcher to demonstrate possible impact of this vulnerability. At this time, AWS has taken possession of the S3 bucket and currently blocks all access, neutralizing any threat. Should this bucket become available to use in the future, affected versions of fsevents will once again become vulnerable. This occurred in August 2023, when the bucket was briefly reinstated in error.
qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (*DoS*) due to improper validation of user-supplied input. This could allow an attacker to render services unavailable or potentially craft other attacks.

qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.
qs Module is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) triggered by excessive recursion in parsing a deeply nested JSON string. An attacker can submit a specially crafted string to crash the module.

Node.js module `qs` is vulnerable to a denial-of-service.  An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by suppling`qs` with a crafted string that deserializes into very large sparse arrays, resulting in the process running out of memory and eventually crashing.

Extend for Node.js contains a prototype pollution flaw. If applications are supplying untrusted input to the extend module, an attacker could modify javaScript Objects that may create a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.

unset-value is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

Node Semver is vulnerable due to improper handling of whitespaces. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by providing a crafted input in order to cause a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).

Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

Node.js cthackers adm-zip package is vulnerable to an arbitrary file write vulnerability via a directory traversal. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying the component with a maliciously crafted archive that, when unpacked, would cause an arbitrary file to be written to the file system.

hosted-git-info is vulnerable to regular expression denial of service (ReDoS) via `fromUrl()`. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted input to consume resources, thus resulting in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition occurring.

Minimatch package contains a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) vulnerability because of improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this flaw by calling the `braceExpand()` function with specific arguments.

Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

Debug-js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service when malicious regular expression input is passed into the `%o` formatter. A remote attacker can exploit this flaw by supplying crafted input to cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.

**Note**: This issue is a duplicate disclosure of **CVE-2017-16137** (**BDSA-2017-3626**).

Debug-js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service when malicious regular expression input is passed into the `%o` formatter. A remote attacker can exploit this flaw by supplying crafted input to cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.

**Note**: **CVE-2017-20165** (**BDSA-2017-4102**) is a duplicate disclosure of this issue.

Node Semver is vulnerable due to improper handling of whitespaces. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by providing a crafted input in order to cause a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).

fstream is vulnerable to an arbitrary file overwrite issue. Attackers could exploit this via hardlink within the `fstream.DirWriter` function, allowing for the overwriting of files on the system enabling the attacker to launch other attacks by editing, or replacing files.

Vercel ms contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a system crash.

**Note:** This vulnerability exists due to an incomplete fix for **CVE-2015-8315**.

brace-expansion is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to a flaw in the process of expansion of expressions. An attacker could leverage this flaw by supplying a crafted regular expression to cause resource overconsumption and make the target application hang.
Tunnel-Agent contains a memory exposure vulnerability due to improper input validation allowing a numeric value for `auth`.
is_my_json_valid is vulnerable to arbitrary code execution via the improper input validation in the `formatName` function.
is_my_json_valid is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) via the `style` format.

Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).

lodash is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. A remote attacker may be able to supply specially crafted input to cause serious confidentiality, integrity and availability impacts to the application. In the past, such vulnerabilities have lead to remote code execution (RCE) in the end application.
Lodash is vulnerable to command injection via the `template` function. An attacker can take advantage of this vulnerability in order to run arbitrary commands.

Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to functionality that allows users to influence protoypes. An attacker could cause a vulnerable application to crash by providing malicious input that modifies JavaScript prototypes within the application. It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.
Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or create a denial-of-service (DoS).

The `package.json` file generated by node package manager for the lodash library contains out-dated information. The `contributors` section of the package.json file contains an URL that has been flagged for serving malware.

Hawk, a HTTP authentication scheme, is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (*ReDoS*) due to its implementation of pattern matching.

js-yaml is vulnerable to code injection due to incorrect parsing of YAML documents. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted YAML file to a vulnerable application using js-yaml and the unsafe `load()` function to parse YAML data.
js-yaml is vulnerable to an excessive resource consumption flaw. A remote attacker able to supply a specially crafted YAML file to an application using js-yaml could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

Moment.js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to an inefficient regular expression in use within the `rfc2822` parsing code.

An attacker could submit a crafted input containing more that 10,000 characters in order to trigger an excessive consumption of resources that result in a slowdown of processing.

moment is vulnerable to path traversal which may lead to the modification of sensitive information within a file directory on the file system. An attacker can exploit this flaw by manipulating directory pathways using unwanted characters to access and modify a resource that is outside the intended directory.

The ini package is vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks.  A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. The impact of this vulnerability is reliant on the ini package parsing a untrusted input.

Request contains a memory disclosure vulnerability due to issues in file `liv/multipart.js` with `multipart` attachments. A remote attacker is able to gain a specified number of non-zero memory due to it being disclosed within the body of the request.

Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.
